title: 108_s2254
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Christen O'Donnell Equestrian Helmet Safety Act of 2004" and grants regarding the use of safe equestrian helmets are discussed. The "Christen O'Donnell Equestrian Helmet Safety Act of 2004" authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to award grants to various organizations to promote the use of approved equestrian helmets. Applicants must submit a grant application meeting specified requirements for review before award. The Secretary allows wide discretion for designing programs to promote approved equestrian helmets in grant applications. The grant under section 2 can be used to encourage wearing approved equestrian helmets, provide assistance to those in need, educate on helmet importance for safety, and a combination of these activities. SEC. 4. REPORT TO CONGRESS.

The Secretary of Commerce must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment on the effectiveness of grants awarded under section 2. The report will list grant recipients, summarize their programs, and include any recommendations for modifying or extending the authority under section 2. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific Senate and House committees.

SEC. 5. STANDARDS. Every equestrian helmet manufactured after 9 months from the enactment of this Act must meet the interim standard ASTM F 1163 and the final standard to be established by the Consumer Product Safety Commission within 60 days of enactment. The Consumer Product Safety Commission will establish a final standard for equestrian helmets that must be certified by an accredited organization. Certain laws will not apply to this process. The final standard for equestrian helmets must be certified by an accredited organization and will take effect within 1 year of issuance. Failure to meet the interim standard will be considered a violation of consumer product safety standards. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS: The Department of Commerce is authorized $100,000 annually for fiscal years 2005-2007, while the Consumer Product Safety Commission is authorized $500,000 for fiscal year 2005. Definitions are provided in Section 7. In this Act, an "approved equestrian helmet" is defined as meeting the interim and final standards specified in the Act, while an "equestrian helmet" is defined as a hard shell head covering for equestrian events.
